articles.headline: G20 Leaders Voice Worry on Trade
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman urged countries that export more than they import to allow their currencies to reflect their overall economic performance.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman urged countries that export more than they import to allow their currencies to reflect their overall economic performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  With the world’s economies moving at two different speeds, fast-growing developing countries are luring money at a pace that, if left unchecked, could set the stage for future problems, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Friday.

articles.headline: Making a Fashion Statement, With or Without Clothes
articles.snippet: Bonaveri, “the Ferraris of the mannequin world,” is among a handful of companies whose brands are as recognizable as the fashion designers whose styles their models show off.
articles.abstract: Bonaveri, “the Ferraris of the mannequin world,” is among a handful of companies whose brands are as recognizable as the fashion designers whose styles their models show off.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENAZZO DI CENTO, Italy  To the untrained eye, the clusters of synthetic body parts scattered on the floor of a vast warehouse in Italy’s heartland looked very much like  well, like clusters of synthetic body parts.

articles.headline: Hyundai’s Swift Growth Lifts Alabama’s Economy
articles.snippet: The car maker laid down roots and provided jobs for thousands in Alabama as local textile mills closed.
articles.abstract: The car maker laid down roots and provided jobs for thousands in Alabama as local textile mills closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Few people in this city 800 miles south of Detroit cared much about the auto industry until Hyundai announced it would build cars here nine years ago.

articles.headline: Healing a Wounded Credit Score
articles.snippet: Many people have seen their credit scores tumble in the last few years, but those scores can be revived if you follow these tips.
articles.abstract: Many people have seen their credit scores tumble in the last few years, but those scores can be revived if you follow these tips.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of consumers have fallen out of favor with the credit scoring gods.

articles.headline: Wisconsin Leads Way as Workers Fight State Cuts
articles.snippet: The unrest in Wisconsin this week over Gov. Scott Walker’s plan to cut the bargaining rights and benefits of public workers is spreading to other states.
articles.abstract: The unrest in Wisconsin this week over Gov. Scott Walker’s plan to cut the bargaining rights and benefits of public workers is spreading to other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unrest in Wisconsin this week over Gov. Scott Walker’s plan to cut the bargaining rights and benefits of public workers is spreading to other states.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: After Long Exile, Sunni Cleric Takes Role in Egypt
articles.snippet: Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi delivered his first sermon in Cairo in 50 years, emerging as a powerful voice in Egypt.
articles.abstract: Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi delivered his first sermon in Cairo in 50 years, emerging as a powerful voice in Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi, an influential Sunni cleric who is banned from the United States and Britain for supporting violence against Israel and American forces in Iraq, delivered his first public sermon here in 50 years on Friday, emerging as a powerful voice in the struggle to shape what kind of Egyptian state emerges from the uprising that toppled Hosni Mubarak.

articles.headline: As House Votes to Cut $60 Billion, Standoff Looms
articles.snippet: The vote showed how the fervor of the midterm elections is driving Republicans’ efforts to shrink the government.
articles.abstract: The vote showed how the fervor of the midterm elections is driving Republicans’ efforts to shrink the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House vote Saturday to slash more than $60 billion from the federal budget shows how powerfully the anti-spending fervor of the fall elections is driving the new Republican majority’s efforts to shrink government. It puts the two parties on a path to a succession of showdowns over the deficit and the nation’s growing debt.

articles.headline: Protesters Take Bahrain Square as Forces Leave
articles.snippet: Protesters surged back into the square, and the monarchy called for peace after two days of violent crackdowns.
articles.abstract: Protesters surged back into the square, and the monarchy called for peace after two days of violent crackdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — Thousands of jubilant protesters surged back into the symbolic heart of Bahrain on Saturday as the government withdrew its security forces, calling for calm after days of violent crackdowns.

articles.headline: The Murdoch in Waiting
articles.snippet: James Murdoch, a possible successor to his father, Rupert, could soon be responsible for about half of the News Corporation.
articles.abstract: James Murdoch, a possible successor to his father, Rupert, could soon be responsible for about half of the News Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON

articles.headline: How a Whistle-Blower Conquered Countrywide
articles.snippet: Michael Winston’s successful court battle against his former employer, Countrywide Financial, offers a glimpse into how business was conducted there during the subprime mania.
articles.abstract: Michael Winston’s successful court battle against his former employer, Countrywide Financial, offers a glimpse into how business was conducted there during the subprime mania.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT does it take to hold your powerful bosses accountable if they try to bully you out the door?

articles.headline: Hiding Details of Dubious Deal, U.S. Invokes National Security
articles.snippet: A computer programmer who said his software could prevent Al Qaeda’s next attack won $20 million in contracts, despite suspicions that his claims were a hoax.
articles.abstract: A computer programmer who said his software could prevent Al Qaeda’s next attack won $20 million in contracts, despite suspicions that his claims were a hoax.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For eight years, government officials turned to Dennis Montgomery, a California computer programmer, for eye-popping technology that he said could catch terrorists. Now, federal officials want nothing to do with him and are going to extraordinary lengths to ensure that his dealings with Washington stay secret.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and James Risen

articles.headline: Jilted in the U.S., a Site Finds Love in India
articles.snippet: Ignighter.com, a site for organizing group dates, wasn’t bringing in much traffic in the U.S. But the founders noticed that it was adding thousands of users a day in India.
articles.abstract: Ignighter.com, a site for organizing group dates, wasn’t bringing in much traffic in the U.S. But the founders noticed that it was adding thousands of users a day in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 2008, three young guys in Manhattan started Ignighter.com, a dating Web site focused on twentysomethings. They sought to set themselves apart by enabling members to set up group dates: One member, serving as a point person, could arrange a date  a movie, say, or a picnic in Central Park  with a group of other people and thereby take some of the awkward edge off of typical dates.

articles.headline: Today’s Lab Rats of Obesity: Furry Couch Potatoes
articles.snippet: Rhesus macaques in an Oregon research center are being turned into couch potatoes with weight problems for study.
articles.abstract: Rhesus macaques in an Oregon research center are being turned into couch potatoes with weight problems for study.
articles.lead_paragraph: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Like many these days, Shiva sits around too much, eating rich, fatty foods and sipping sugary drinks. He has the pot belly to prove it, one that nearly touches the floor  when he’s on all fours, that is.

articles.headline: Deficits Reshape the Debate as Republicans Jockey for 2012
articles.snippet: The issues of budget deficits and the nation’s growing debt load are shaping the early stages of the race for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination.
articles.abstract: The issues of budget deficits and the nation’s growing debt load are shaping the early stages of the race for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana described the nation’s fiscal condition in dark terms more often reserved for a terror threat, declaring, “We face an enemy lethal to liberty and even more implacable than those America has defeated before.”

articles.headline: In a Town Built Upon Patronage, a Test of Egypt’s New Order
articles.snippet: One task of Egypt’s revolution is to replace a system knit together by patronage, greased by bribes and guided by the principle that the governing party knows best.
articles.abstract: One task of Egypt’s revolution is to replace a system knit together by patronage, greased by bribes and guided by the principle that the governing party knows best.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGOUR, Egypt  In a town he represented in Parliament for 46 years, Kamal al-Shazli left his mark. There is the Kamal al-Shazli School on Kamal al-Shazli Street, around the corner from the Kamal al-Shazli Mosque, which is a little ways from the cafe where Mr. Shazli held court when he was the only man in town who got things done.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Son Warns of Civil War as Libyan Protests Widen
articles.snippet: As clashes reached the capital, Tripoli, the son of the Libyan leader raised the threat of renewed Western “colonization” if protesters threw off his father’s rule.
articles.abstract: As clashes reached the capital, Tripoli, the son of the Libyan leader raised the threat of renewed Western “colonization” if protesters threw off his father’s rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  A five-day-old uprising in Libya took control of its second-largest city of Benghazi and spread for the first time to the capital of Tripoli late on Sunday as the heir-apparent son of its strongman, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, warned Libyans in a televised speech that their oil-rich country would fall into civil war and even renewed Western “colonization” if they threw off his father’s 40-year-long rule.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mona El-Naggar

articles.headline: Next Question for Tunisia: The Role of Islam in Politics
articles.snippet: When security forces rushed to protect brothels last week it marked a new phase of the revolution as Tunisians fiercely debate the role of Islam in politics.
articles.abstract: When security forces rushed to protect brothels last week it marked a new phase of the revolution as Tunisians fiercely debate the role of Islam in politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS  The Tunisian revolution that overthrew decades of authoritarian rule has entered a delicate new phase in recent days over the role of Islam in politics. Tensions mounted here last week when military helicopters and security forces were called in to carry out an unusual mission: protecting the city’s brothels from a mob of zealots.

articles.headline: Blogs Wane as the Young Drift to Sites Like Twitter
articles.snippet: Long-form blogs were once the outlet of choice, but now sites like Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr are favored.
articles.abstract: Long-form blogs were once the outlet of choice, but now sites like Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr are favored.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Like any aspiring filmmaker, Michael McDonald, a high school senior, used a blog to show off his videos. But discouraged by how few people bothered to visit, he instead started posting his clips on Facebook, where his friends were sure to see and comment on his editing skills.

articles.headline: At Newsweek, a Humble and Frugal Tina Brown
articles.snippet: Since the Daily Beast Web site merged with Newsweek, the accomplished editor is eager to avoid any hype about her plan to turn the struggling newsweekly around.
articles.abstract: Since the Daily Beast Web site merged with Newsweek, the accomplished editor is eager to avoid any hype about her plan to turn the struggling newsweekly around.
articles.lead_paragraph: There will be no celebrity-studded gala with fireworks over New York Harbor this time. No brash predictions of upending the magazine business.

articles.headline: After iPad’s Head Start, Rival Tablets Are Poised to Flood Offices
articles.snippet: A number of new tablets geared toward businesses are expected to give the iPad, which has had the market largely to itself, a run for its money.
articles.abstract: A number of new tablets geared toward businesses are expected to give the iPad, which has had the market largely to itself, a run for its money.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The billboards promoting the iPad have a simple message: The tablet is a device for leisure, to be held on one’s lap while lounging on a couch in casual clothes, to watch a film or read a magazine.

articles.headline: In Prime-Time TV, Networks Losing the War for 10 P.M.
articles.snippet: The 10 p.m. time slot has become an expensive graveyard where many networks have seen hourlong dramas stagnate.
articles.abstract: The 10 p.m. time slot has become an expensive graveyard where many networks have seen hourlong dramas stagnate.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past several years, many broadcast network executives have looked at the ratings for their 10 p.m. shows and lamented that it has become impossible to build a true, breakout hit at that hour anymore.

articles.headline: 2 Platforms, With 2 Sets of Problems
articles.snippet: Magazine publishers have a tough choice: an exclusive, pricey deal with the wildly popular Apple conduit, or Google’s open, less expensive and less trafficked vehicle.
articles.abstract: Magazine publishers have a tough choice: an exclusive, pricey deal with the wildly popular Apple conduit, or Google’s open, less expensive and less trafficked vehicle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Digital subscriptions, a grail for the mainstream media that often seemed more like a mirage, took on some firm if not altogether friendly dimensions last week.

articles.headline: TV Industry Taps Social Media to Keep Viewers’ Attention
articles.snippet: As more and more people chat on Facebook and Twitter while watching TV, networks are trying to figure out how to capitalize.
articles.abstract: As more and more people chat on Facebook and Twitter while watching TV, networks are trying to figure out how to capitalize.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time the first ballot is opened at the Academy Awards next Sunday, millions of people will be chatting about the awards show on the Internet. And ABC will be ready.

articles.headline: U.S. Sets 21st-Century Goal: Building a Better Patent Office
articles.snippet: Only in the last three years has the federal Patent and Trademark Office begun to accept a majority of its applications in digital form.
articles.abstract: Only in the last three years has the federal Patent and Trademark Office begun to accept a majority of its applications in digital form.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who emphasizes American innovation, says modernizing the federal Patent and Trademark Office is crucial to “winning the future.” So at a time when a quarter of patent applications come from California, and many of those from Silicon Valley, the patent office is opening its first satellite office  in Detroit.

articles.headline: Google Trying to Avoid Antitrust Fight in Europe
articles.snippet: As Google’s ambitions have grown so has the scrutiny of antitrust agencies on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly in Europe.
articles.abstract: As Google’s ambitions have grown so has the scrutiny of antitrust agencies on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — At the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the hottest ticket in recent years has invariably been an invitation to Google’s lavish private party, and 2011 was no exception.

articles.headline: As Republicans See a Mandate on Budget Cuts, Others See Risk
articles.snippet: Republicans may be risking the same kind of electoral backlash that President Obama and the Democrats suffered after they were perceived as overreaching.
articles.abstract: Republicans may be risking the same kind of electoral backlash that President Obama and the Democrats suffered after they were perceived as overreaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In Congress and in statehouses, Republican lawmakers and governors are claiming a broad mandate from last year’s elections as they embark on an aggressive campaign of cutting government spending and taking on public unions. Their agenda echoes in its ambition what President Obama and Democrats tried after winning office in their own electoral wave in 2008.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Grip Falters as His Forces Take On Protesters
articles.snippet: Several senior Libyan officials broke with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, as forces loyal to him struck back at mounting protests against his 40-year rule.
articles.abstract: Several senior Libyan officials broke with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, as forces loyal to him struck back at mounting protests against his 40-year rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  The faltering government of the Libyan strongman, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, struck back at mounting protests against his 40-year rule as security forces and militiamen backed by helicopters and warplanes besieged parts of the capital on Monday, according to witnesses and news reports from Tripoli.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mona El-Naggar

articles.headline: BP to Pay $7.2 Billion for Stake in Oil Fields in India
articles.snippet: The deal with Reliance is the second major agreement signed by BP in recent months. The group also made a deal with Russia’s Rosneft to drill in the Arctic.
articles.abstract: The deal with Reliance is the second major agreement signed by BP in recent months. The group also made a deal with Russia’s Rosneft to drill in the Arctic.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  The British oil giant BP said on Monday that it would pay $7.2 billion to buy into India’s fast-growing oil and gas industry. It is BP’s second big deal in two months, as it seeks to rebuild after last year’s Gulf of Mexico oil spill.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Julia Werdigier
